text: I think product updates often are good content IF they're rewritten for the different audience in mind. Your standard product update sent to existing customers may not make a whole lot of sense out of context. So if the content is reworked for a TOFU audience then I say yes

text:
Hey content strategists,
Have you ever used non-traditional KPIs to measure success—for example: amount of JOY delivered to an audience? :thinking_face:

(context in the thread :arrow_down: )

elements.text:
Hey content strategists,
Have you ever used non-traditional KPIs to measure success—for example: amount of JOY delivered to an audience?
(context in the thread

text:
Context:

Working in B2B, I previously measured content success in:
- Traffic it brought
- Engagement it received 
- Signups and MQLs it generated
- Upsells/cross-sells it led to

These are all standard, quantitative ways to do it—but they are also about what WE creators or companies get from the audience, rather than being about what THEY got from us. 

This quarter, I’ve been working with with a B2B team on a comic book and made “spreading joy” as an actual marketing objective, measured in:

- :raised_hands: the level of enthusiasm you find in people’s feedback
- :rocket: the presence of words like ‘enjoyable’, ‘amazing’, ‘made me laugh’ in their comments
- :heart: the presence of heart-like emojis

And now I am wondering if anyone else has tried a similar approach and/or seen somebody else do something like this?

elements.text:
Context:

Working in B2B, I previously measured content success in:
- Traffic it brought
- Engagement it received 
- Signups and MQLs it generated
- Upsells/cross-sells it led to

These are all standard, quantitative ways to do it—but they are also about what WE creators or companies get from the audience, rather than being about what THEY got from us. 

This quarter, I’ve been working with with a B2B team on a comic book and made “spreading joy” as an actual marketing objective, measured in:

-

the level of enthusiasm you find in people’s feedback
-

the presence of words like ‘enjoyable’, ‘amazing’, ‘made me laugh’ in their comments
-

the presence of heart-like emojis

And now I am wondering if anyone else has tried a similar approach and/or seen somebody else do something like this?

text:
My answers is probably not but <@U01JGE01ZA8> made a great point about reassessing what we manage in this post: 
<https://first500words.org/featured-snippets/|https://first500words.org/featured-snippets/>

(Context is that featured snippets often answer a query without the searcher clicking to your site).

attachments.title: Featured Snippets: Hero Or Hype? - First500Words
attachments.text: Featured snippets are a neat way for marketers to nab the top spot on Google but are they worth the effort of evaluating how you track clicks?
attachments.fallback: First500Words: Featured Snippets: Hero Or Hype? - First500Words

text:
I read this emoji report a few weeks back and while most of it wasn’t that surprising it did get me thinking about things in a similar way to how you’re measuring Joy. Essentially, using emoji reactions to gauge how ppl are feeling about your content. I like how you’ve taken it even further. :raised_hands:
<https://www.brandwatch.com/reports/the-emoji-report/>
